 Summary of what happened
 
 On April 27, a Lexington, MA, parent, David Parker, was arrested by the Lexington police and charged with "trespassing" at his son's elementary school during a scheduled meeting with the principal and the town's Director of Education over his objections to homosexual curriculum materials. Parker had asked for notification and possible opt-out for his son for homosexual curriculum or ad-hoc discussions by adults in his son's kindergarten class. After several months of communication, he was repeatedly told that his requests are "not possible." He finally said he would not leave the meeting until this was resolved.
 
 After being arrested and spending the night in jail, Parker was arraigned on Thursday, April 28, in Concord District Court. When he informed Judge Robert McKenna that he had not been allowed to call his lawyer, the judge scolded him for not being respectful. Parker was released on $1,000 surety bond. He was officially informed that he may not set foot on any school property in Lexington, or he will be arrested again for trespassing. A hearing was set for June 1, followed by court appearances on Aug. 2 and Sept. 19.
 
 New superintendent is no different. During the summer, Dr. Paul Ash took over as superintendent of Lexington Schools from William Hurley, who was serving in an interim capacity. On Sept. 22, Ash announced he was ordering teachers to give NO notice when discussing homosexual relationships with children, even in elementary grades. (see report below). Ash also continues to enforce the no-trespass order against Parker. At the Sept. 19 court appearance, Judge McKenna gave Ash an extra 30 days to decide whether to lift the ban, after Ash had complained he hadn't had enought time.
 
 
 Statement by David Parker (April 27, 2005):
 
 "I, David Parker, am the father of a kindergarten student at Estabrook Elementary School in Lexington, Massachusetts. Since the beginning of this school year, my wife and I have learned that school materials and discussions about gay-headed households/same-sex union issues have been exposed to the children. There are definitive plans to increase the teacher/staff/adult mediated discussions of these subjects.
 
 "We have officially stated on many occasions-to the Lexington school administration-a request that we be notified when these discussions are planned, and want our 6-year-old opted out of such situations when arising "spontaneously".
 
 "Our parental requests for our own child were flat-out denied with no effort at accommodation. In our meeting on April 27, I, insisted that such accommodation be made and refused to leave the meeting room. I was informed that I would be arrested."

 Extremely enlightening. This is the timeline of events starting in January and leading up to the final meeting and arrest on April 27, 2005.
 
 Original book brought home by kindergarten class.
 Here's the book, "Who's in a Family," that started it all. It came home with the Parker's kindergarten-age son in January. (Also, some of the books given out in other grades.)
 
 Parkers attend elementary school's "Anti-Bias Committee" meetings. 
 Here's what the Parkers witnessed (and were told) -- a real eye-opener. In Massachusetts (and other places) much of a school's radical agenda gets in under the radar through these semi-official committes of radical teachers, administrators, and some parents, which operate outside of any formal oversight.
 
 Other family in David Parker's elementary school leaves town over homosexual agenda in school.
 David Parker is an unusual -- very special -- man, in that he was willing to stand up and fight for his rights. Unfortunately, too many parents feel so overwhelmed and or intimidated that they see their only option is to leave. (And this is exactly what the so-called "diversity" crowd likes to see happen!)
 
 The night before arrest: Parker addresses the Lexington School Committee with his concerns, gets ignored. 
 The night before the final meeting (and arrest) David Parker spoke passionately before the School Committee about his situation. And they rudely ignored him. They wouldn't even give him the courtesy of a reply.

Let me tell you guys a little about Christian love and grade-school from the perspective of my family.
 
 As many of you know, I used to be Christian. When my son was three I kicked his abusive, biological father out and divorced him. Since then we have never heard a word nor has he offered an ounce of support. Oh well, good riddance. However, when my son hit kindergarden he started acting out and was verbal about wanting a dad. I signed us up for Big Brothers of Minnesota and talked to congregation elders. Nobody at church seemed to have the time. But I kept praying.
 
 Two years later Big Brothers came through with a mentor. Great guy - patient, generous, loving, plays catch, goes fishing, helps me when I need it. Easily the best man I have ever known. He stayed committed to my son for nearly four years when we decided to make it legal. We went to court and this great guy legally became my son's father. My son is happier, more patient, and turning into an amazing young man. The amazing man our lives were blessed with is gay.
 
 When my congregation found out that I allowed a gay man to mentor my son I got plenty of criticism - but no offers to take on the role.
 
 At school one day a kid was using the word "gay" in a deragatory manner. My son asked them to stop because his dad was gay. The response from these kids from "normal" families was to throw him down on the bus, shove garbage in his mouth, and to threaten him with beatings if he even saw his own father again. Thats what these innocents have learned about being gay from society, church and home. In high school I knew gay kid who had his head pounded into a locker daily. You bet your XXX gay tolerance needs to be taught. 
 
 Actions speak louder than words. We don't go to church anymore. And I have seen how a loving man behaves.

Well now, I think there is quite a difference here between what goes on in college and what goes on in the first few grades of elementary school (which is what the video was dealing with). The bottom line here is that you're bringing moralistic values into the classroom, and I have a problem with that. I'd have just as much of a problem if it were someone bringing in moralistic values from their religion. It's the same thing--schools aren't for that purpose. You say you want students to be able to think on their own, but I suspect you wouldn't teach these children that some people don't agree with your take on gay relations, give them both sides, and tell them to make up their own minds. Would you? The reason you wouldn't is that your moralistic values are that YOUR way is the right one, and so you would be bringing your moralistic values into the classroom.

 
 Actually, when issues related to gay people come up in my college classes, I DO say that different people have different views on such matters and that all viewpoints should be listened to and considered carefully. I do not in any way try to impose my beliefs about being gay or about gay rights on my students. That would be unprofessional, in my opinion. I am not in class to express my views. I am in class to teach my subject, which is history. I am usually reticent to tell students my views on things, and I do so only when they ask me directly. I always qualify my answers by saying that these are my personal views. There is a difference between presenting the scholarship and letting students debate and discuss historical issues and me telling them what I think personally. I also do not advocate for any political position, and I am always careful not to say negative or postive things about current political leaders, since it's not my job to do that. It's up to students to make up their own minds. The values that I bring to my college classrooms are values about how to think, how to analyze evidence, how to use primary and secondary sources, and how to write clearly and effectively. 
 
 When it comes to the first few grades of elementary school, I think that students do need to learn how to behave with others, and that is clearly a major goal of early education: teaching students how to treat others in a social setting. If we just say, "Let the parents do it," then we wind up with chaos in the classrooms, which is what in some cases we have now. I don't know how we as a society can effectively improve parenting, but we can work on the schools. I agree with you that ideally, parents will teach students how to behave, but we don't live in an ideal world, and if schools don't require good behavior, then no one can learn. This is not the same as "moralizing" in a broad sense, but it is teaching rules and how to act. 
 
 As for whether teaching "morals" is the same as teaching religion, it is not. Teaching religion in the public schools is specifically prohibited, and the Supreme Court has been quite firm on this. Teaching "morals" more broadly is not prohibited, and it is an open and contested question how much schools should teach in this area. I tend to agree with you that teaching "morals" ought to be limited to teaching respect for others and good behavior. But if public schools teach some kind of civic virtue, that is not the same as schools teaching religious doctrine. The former is permitted; the latter has been ruled unconstitutional. 
 
 Btw, I did not see the video posted by Archangel, because I have him on ignore. So I do not know what the content of this video is, or what kind of school setting the video captured. I will say that the rules for private schools are very different from the rules for public schools. Public schools cannot teach religion as doctrine. Private schools can.

Actions Have Hurt Community (Anti- David Parker letter)
 Lexington Minuteman ^ | August 4, 2005 | Craig Cyr
 
 Posted on 08/04/2005 7:46:19 PM PDT by lexfreedom
 
 Letter: Actions have hurt community Thursday, August 4, 2005
 
 This is my perspective in the David Parker matter. Here's a little background. My wife, three daughters and I moved from California to Lexington in 2001. My daughter was a kindergartner with Mr. Parker's son this past year..
 
 We chose to move to Lexington after looking at a myriad of towns. We sought a community with a commitment to quality education and one that reflected our belief in openness, inclusion and diversity. This type of decision-making is based on "the social economics of townships." Towns are differentiated with diverse values and services, thereby, providing consumer choice. Families are social consumers in this way. After becoming a member of this community, I expect to reap its benefits, i.e., openness and inclusion.
 
 I support Mr. Parker's right to his beliefs, but do not agree with either the premise or the structure of his proposal. His "premise" would result in the school having to marginalize the existence of some families. In its structure, his request is impractical.
 
 His wish to disrupt school activities, based on spontaneous discussions wherever his child is present with a resulting parent notification and the removal of his child from a school activity, is unworkable no matter what the subject matter. Without definitions of what discussions qualify as offensive to Mr. Parker, and without every adult in the school being made aware of both the student and the hazy definitions, how could the school possibly satisfy his desired outcome?
 
 I also have a hard time reconciling Mr. Parker's words with his actions. Instead of working to get a solution that could be accommodated, he had one proposal. Instead of running for School Committee to institute change through community channels, he chose to be an activist. He chose to be arrested. He chose to align himself with outside groups to obtain administrative, media, tactical, financial and legal support.
 
 He chose to use local, regional and national media to distort his case and denigrate Lexington. He chose to bring his crusade to communities as far away as Maine, just recently, speaking at the "Wake UP Maine Tour," a statewide rally opposed to homosexual rights. These conscious decisions speak volumes.
 
 Mr. Parker's states he is "anguished that his arrest has caused any pain to this community." His continued promotion of this crusade does nothing but cause the community anguish and pain.
 
 His actions speak louder than his words. 
 
 Mr. Parker is an anti-gay activist. This letter tells the truth about what happened. Of course, a rightwing fascist pig like AA would see it differently.

I always qualify my answers by saying that these are my personal views. There is a difference between presenting the scholarship and letting students debate and discuss historical issues and me telling them what I think personally. I also do not advocate for any political position, and I am always careful not to say negative or postive things about current political leaders, since it's not my job to do that. It's up to students to make up their own minds. The values that I bring to my college classrooms are values about how to think, how to analyze evidence, how to use primary and secondary sources, and how to write clearly and effectively. 
 
 When it comes to the first few grades of elementary school, I think that students do need to learn how to behave with others, and that is clearly a major goal of early education: teaching students how to treat others in a social setting. If we just say, "Let the parents do it," then we wind up with chaos in the classrooms, which is what in some cases we have now. I don't know how we as a society can effectively improve parenting, but we can work on the schools. I agree with you that ideally, parents will teach students how to behave, but we don't live in an ideal world, and if schools don't require good behavior, then no one can learn. This is not the same as "moralizing" in a broad sense, but it is teaching rules and how to act. 

 
 Agreed that it's important to teach them how to behave toward others, but it seems to me that if they're calling other kids names, then make rules about name-calling and punish them when those rules are broken. The impression I get here is that some here feel that name-calling when it comes to gays is somehow more important in terms of prevention than any other issue, and I don't see why. Why is this the one issue we have to get to the root of "prejudices" with children in schools and not other areas? After all, kids commit suicide later over lots of issues related to self-esteem--it seems to me that if we're going to have a message for them, the message should be not to make fun of each other over ANYTHING, not just the gay issue. Now you may reply and say "but we should do it with other areas too", but if we start doing that with all other areas, our schools turn into social work clinics, and I just don't think that's what schools should be about. So basically, schools already have means in place (or should) to teach this way of behaving--it's called rules. If kids bully, they've broken the rules. Punish them. Is that not sufficient to take care of anti-gay bullying and name-calling in schools?
 
 
As for whether teaching "morals" is the same as teaching religion, it is not. Teaching religion in the public schools is specifically prohibited, and the Supreme Court has been quite firm on this. Teaching "morals" more broadly is not prohibited, and it is an open and contested question how much schools should teach in this area.

 
 Ok, then what if someone is teaching morals you don't like that aren't coming from their religion? A non-religious homophobe, for instance, teaching that gays are bad. The point is that teaching moralistic values in schools is just not a good precedent (religious or otherwise), because ultimately it comes down to someone's morals being given precedent. If we ARE going to teach moralistic values in schools then it needs to be something EVERYONE agrees with, and certainly not everyone does on gay-related issues. 
 
 It's also interesting that you're drawing a distinction here between religion and morality, because I don't see you and others doing that in other areas, such as the president and other govt. officials legislating from his views of morality when those moral views come out of his religion. You can't have it both ways in terms of the 1st amendment. People have moral views as a result of all sorts of reasons, religion included. You probably wouldn't want someone teaching their moral view that gay sex is wrong, so I see no reason your view that living as a gay person, out, should be taught either. 
 
 
I tend to agree with you that teaching "morals" ought to be limited to teaching respect for others and good behavior. But if public schools teach some kind of civic virtue, that is not the same as schools teaching religious doctrine. The former is permitted; the latter has been ruled unconstitutional. 

 
 There's a fine line there. And there's sometimes no line at all.

Someone observed earlier that the school in question in the original link in this thread is a private school, not a public school. I would like to point out that you cannot use an example of a private school as evidence of what is being taught in public schools. They are different. Private schools can teach any morals or religious beliefs that they want. We have conservative Christian private schools that teach creationism, not evolution. They can do that if they want to. A Quaker private school can teach whatever morals the administration chooses to teach. Parents can choose to send their children there or not. It's a private school. Private schools can teach religious doctrine as they choose. Public schools cannot teach religious doctrine. That's been ruled on clearly by the Supreme Court. Teaching religious doctrine is out of bounds in the public schools. 
 
 Archangel can object all he wants to a private school teaching ideas that he dislikes about gay people, but he can't do anything about it unless he funds the private school, or sits on its board, or is a parent of a child attending the school. It's a private matter up to the school. What is taught in public schools is more open to public debate, because public schools are public. School boards are usually elected by voters, and they shape the broad policy in public schools. 
 
 I think it's important to draw a distinction between public and private schools when people argue about what schools are teaching.

 I think that religion is the biggest barrier to gay people achieving equal rights under the law and fair treatment in the society. I think you are right about that, Sam. In the United States, conservative Christians are the biggest opponents of fairness and equality for gay people, just as in the past these same conservative Christians, or their ancestors, were the biggest opponents of racial equality and of equality for women. Conservative Christians were also the biggest supporters of slavery. The conservative Southen Baptist Convention came into being because its founders supported slavery. The Southern Baptist Convention was formed out of a split in the Baptist Church between anti-slavery and pro-slavery Baptists. 
 
 It's also true that some of the biggest supporters of equality and fairness are and long have been Christians, though they tend not to be conservative Christians or fundamentalist Christians. There has always been a progressive tradition within Christianity, and progressive Christians have led the struggles to abolish slavery, to support women's equality, to end poverty and economic inequality, to stop various wars, and to bring about racial justice. Today we have progressive Christians taking courageous stands in the struggle for equality for gay people. Think about those young people who made the Equality Rides to conservative Christian colleges around the nation this past spring to speak out as Christians on behalf of equality for gay people. 
 
 So while I understand your anger at conservative Christians, who have done and continue to do us so much harm, I think we also need to recognize and support those progressive Christians who stand for social justice in all its dimensions.

"By providing the educational community with IT'S ELEMENTARY, Chasnoff and Cohen have provided...college instructors, workshop leaders, facilitators, and social activists one of the most powerful and important resources available for initiating dialogue, encouraging individual self-development, and pushing forth toward educational and social change on a topic that too few have successfully accessibly addressed."
 EdChange Multicultural Pavilion 
 
 
 IT'S ELEMENTARY is, to date, the most important film (and one of the most important pieces of work in any medium) available which addresses gay and lesbian issues in a grade school setting. Debra Chasnoff and Helen Cohen, the filmmakers, visited six elementary and middle schools in which teachers used a variety of techniques to introduce discussions about gay and lesbian issues in their classrooms.
 
 While the film is worth it's price for the teaching strategies employed and displayed by the educators whose classrooms were highlighted, the power of It's Elementary transcends teaching techniques and pedagogy. Chasnoff and Cohen broach topics that even people in the Multicultural Education community often find difficult to discuss. More importantly, the film challenges several assumptions made by educators and lay-people alike about student interest in, and ability to intelligently discuss, gay issues. And it does so in a way that is accessible, not intimidating, for viewers who most desperately need to be pulled into a discussion about gay issues as they pertain to self, school, and society.
 
 Even teachers and administrators who routinely hear students throw around terms like "XXXXXX" or "gay" tend to be more comfortable believing that those students are not ready to discuss the bigger implications of this "name-calling," maybe because they, themselves, have never had an opportunity to engage in a dialogue about gay issues. Even as our society is becoming more comfortable exploring issues of race and gender, dialogue about sexual orientation remains taboo, even in many of the most liberal circles. In such a context and climate, the most critical assumption challenged by the film is that young students are not ready to discuss oppression, discrimination, and specifically, homophobia and heterosexism. This assumption is shattered in the unforgettable opening sequence through a manufactured exchange of ideologies between a Congressman who prefers such topics to be left out of the classroom and a group of elementary school students who demonstrate that they're not only ready to discuss it, but that they may be more ready than a hefty percentage of adults. Then, throughout the rest of the film, the students continue to demonstrate and reiterate their readiness.
 
 By providing the educational community with It's Elementary, Chasnoff and Cohen have provided me and other college instructors, workshop leaders, facilitators, and social activists one of the most powerful and important resources available for initiating dialogue, encouraging individual self-development, and pushing forth toward educational and social change on a topic that too few have successfully accessibly addressed.
 
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 "[It's Elementary] serves as a model for educators who want to deal with the subject of lesbians and gays but don't know where to begin."
 Barry Walters
 San Francisco Examiner 
 
 Full Review:
 
 Taking Gay Issues Into Classrooms; Documentary It's Elementary Designed to Enlighten Teachers, Parents, and Administrators
 "What we found is that by third grade almost all children have already been exposed to information about gay people," documentary filmmaker Debra Chasnoff in regard to her latest project, It's Elementary:Talking About Gay Issues In School. Chasnoff, who won the best short documentary Oscar in 1992 for Deadly Deception: General Electric, Nuclear Weapons and Our Environment is obviously no stranger to controversy. "We want to influence the kind of public debate that has heated up around teaching kids about gays and lesbians," says collaborator Helen Cohen of the film that will have its world premiere June 5 at the Herbst Theater. "We'd like to inject a little sanity, as well as inspire educators who need to recognize they have a responsibility to make schools a safe place for everyone, where issues like prejudice and homophobia can be addressed."
 
 The result is what could become one of the most important films ever devoted to lesbian and gay issues. Chasnoff and Cohen's 75 minute film is designed to enlighten teachers, parents and administrators how to teach elementary and middle school students about lesbians and gays.
 
 By going into the classroom with teachers and students from the first to the eighth grade, Chasnoff and Cohen demystify an issue that has become a rallying point for the right to create an unnecessary hysteria that paralyzes schools, worries parents and confuses students. No matter how informed you think you may be about homophobia and what is or is not appropriate for children to discuss, it is another thing entirely to watch 6-7 and 8 year old kids talk about how they don't like being called names like "XXXXXX" and think it's unfair that two men or two women shouldn't be able to get married.
 
 As they point out themselves, kids already have been exposed to ideas about gay people on the news, in movies, during talk shows and from their parents. They don't see what the big deal is about discussing those issues in school. "The youngest kids have a sense of fairness and a kind of instinctual philosophy about gay people," says Cohen. "As they grow older, they become more difficult to reach because of the negative things they've picked up." "When you talk about lesbian and gay issues in the classroom, " explains Chasnoff, "people immediately think teachers are talking about sex because the right has programmed us to think that way. We found that elementary kids aren't interested in all that, but they are concerned about name-calling, issues about families that don't consist of one mommy and one daddy as well as examining stereotypes about lesbians and gays. The kids are often much more relaxed about the topic than their parents."
 
 The locally based team went into the classrooms of seven schools, both public and private, in New York, Madison, Wis., Cambridge, Mass., and San Francisco. It was difficult to find schools that would welcome the filmmakers, and some students were kept home by their parents on the days that the cameras would be in the schools. What did get onto film is not only impressive for how sophisticated and rational the discussion is among students, but also for the clarity and ingenuity of the teaching. The combination serves as a model for educators who want to deal with the subject of lesbians and gays but don't know where to begin.
 
 The film starts with Sen. Robert Smith (R-N.H.) talking about gay people as "filth" and "trash," then cuts to a fourth-grade class in New York brainstorming about what comes to mind when they hear the words "lesbian" and "gay" and where they get their ideas from. Clips of "Home Alone 2," "Kindergarten Cop" and "Ace Ventura: Pet Detective" - all PG movies popular with kids - follow with characters spouting homophobic remarks. First- and second-graders from Madison then share a book they've created about gays and lesbians. A parent who says she doesn't approve of homosexuality says that the fact that the topic comes up in school allows her to broach the subject at home and share her own views.
 
 Although a handful of teachers involved in the project came out to their students, most of them are straight and have learned to be at ease dealing with the subject. As one points out, straight teachers are possibly more likely to feel safe talking to students about gays and lesbians because they can't be accused of "recruiting" children to their "lifestyle," as the right fears. Minority women point out that it was important for them to overcome their own biases and make the classroom comfortable for children of different backgrounds, including those with lesbian or gay parents, particularly because they know first-hand what it's like to feel discrimination.
 
 Although the final cut of the film was finished only days ago, the pair created a trailer for the film and showed the footage to 500 educators around the country. "They were absolutely beside themselves," remembers Chasnoff. "They demanded copies of the film right now!" While sifting through the hours of footage, it did occur to the filmmakers that conservatives might seize the film as an opportunity to further distort the issue. "We had to put that aside," says Cohen. "Anything can be taken out of context, even this film." "I wanted to take an optimistic approach," Chasnoff elaborates. "We can stop being on the defense. I would love to sit and watch a right-wing group see this film and explain why this topic should be censored. I want them to tell me why a student can't have his or her questions answered, why a little girl shouldn't be allowed to read an essay she wrote about her two mommies. Personally, I don't welcome an attack. But I do welcome a real dialogue about why this issue is perceived to be so dangerous."
 
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 "...a sterling production...highly recommended for parents, educators, and other adults."
 4 stars
 Booklist 
 
 Full Review:
 
 This enlightening program eavesdrops on activities and discussions about gay issues in various elementary and middle-school classrooms across the country. While this might seem like a fiery topic for a grade-school curriculum, the emerging theme is respect, tolerance, and acceptance rather than sexual orientation. In a New England Quaker school, gay pride activities include assembly programs and picture-book readings, while New York City third-graders listen to their classmate read a winning Mother's Day essay about her two lesbian mothers. A Wisconsin teacher shares artwork and photographs with his class as he introduces the contributions of such well-known homosexuals as pop singer Melissa Etheridge and artist Michelangelo. A photography exhibit about gay and lesbian families is well received at another school, despite initial reservations from both faculty and parents. Selected film, television, and newsreel clips and occasional interviews add dimension, but it is the low-key classroom footage (and blase response from students, who seem more accepting than reactionary adults) that is memorable. This sterling production from Debra Chasnoff (Deadly Deception [BKL F 15 93]) and Helen S. Cohen is highly recommended for parents, educators, and other adults.
 
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 Chair, Education Department, Dartmouth College

 "Groundbreaking - a 'must-see' for educational policy makers everywhere."
 Luis O. Reyes
 New York City School Board

 "If schools are serious about preparing students for the future, we have to help them handle the diversity that exists in our communities. By addressing gay issues, we will prevent violence and foster equality. IT'S ELEMENTARY is an extremely moving portrait of how it can be done."

WASHINGTON - Truth Wins Out today called a lawsuit settlement between Parents and Friends of Ex-Gays (PFOX) and Arlington County (Virginia) schools a capitulation that puts the health and well being of students at risk. The agreement allows PFOX to hand out pseudoscientific fliers at middle schools that will urge students to visit a website that refers them to a troubled counselor who was permanently expelled from the American Counseling Association. 
 
 "Arlington County failed in its responsibility to protect students and ensure that they are not harmed by disreputable therapists or dangerous practices," said Truth Wins Out's Executive Director Wayne Besen. "The content provided by PFOX is medically reckless and morally reprehensible and no school system should have a hand in its distribution."
 
 Truth Wins Out contends that by focusing on the phony question of equal access, Arlington County missed an opportunity to win this case by pointing out that PFOX is a discredited group that is driven by Richard Cohen, a bizarre therapist who was permanently expelled by the American Counseling Association. Cohen's peculiar brand of therapy includes banging a tennis racket while yelling a parent's name, caressing clients who sit on his lap and blaming the angry spirits of dead relatives for causing homosexuality. 
 
 "It is clear that if the methods practiced by Cohen had been made central to this legal battle, PFOX would have been railroaded out of court," said Besen. "Even conservatives would have recoiled when they saw Cohen's methods as displayed on national television. Arlington County could have made a strong case that they have a duty to protect vulnerable children from the predatory therapies promoted by PFOX."

As promised I have now viewed the It's Elementary video. It shows how a handful of grade and middle school classrooms discussing gays and lesbians. 
 
 One of the main excersizes is simply telling the kids to brainstorm - write down whatever comes to their minds when they think of gays and lesbians. They then tackle the items that are stereotypes and address where they learned them. It then shows how very prevelant negative images and language about gays can be found all over the place, on TV and in films (even those aimed at children).
 
 They also talk to students about using negative gay-oriented names (i.e., f*g) or using "gay" as an insult.
 
 One teacher also told his students about well-known artists, musicians, academics and politicians who were gay/lesbian to show that they are like anyone else and contribute positively to society and history.
 
 There were a couple of grade school students who spoke about their gay families or teachers.
 
 One teacher did a great visual metaphor for the kids about how much harder it is for him to be a good person/friend/teacher when he has to worry about hiding the fact that he is gay. (He used a soccer ball - and showed how hard it would be to play hiding one of his legs.)
 
 They also showed the teachers discussing it and their various levels of comfort. 
 
 They showed news reports that reported on the high number of suicides by gay youth and the fact a huge number of gay-hate crimes are perpetrated by teens. Those stats and wanting to create a environment where all their students could feel safe to be who they are or speak about their family were why it was felt that this type of tolerance education was important.
 
 Now for the accusations.
 
 It is not indoctrination. Most of the teachers were straight and the video also showed the reasonable arguments of those who had concerns about whether/when this was appropriate for kids. (It also showed some very ugly actions/words/reactions from some anti-gay rights activists.) 
 
 Many of the kids did voice their discomfort with it and were not belittled for that at all. One of the rules before engaging in the discussion was "there are no wrong answers." The older kids debated the age-appropriateness of the material and gay marriage.
 
 Sex was not discussed. As a matter of fact, when one middle school student asked a gay guest speaker how he "did it" the speaker said he was not allowed to speak about his sex life, that it was not appropriate nor was it the topic at hand.
 
 Now for the controversial vegetable metaphor. The little boy was NOT suggesting that everyone try gay sex. His class was reading a story called My Two Mums about a little girl who told her teacher that she had two moms and the teacher got angry and told her that she couldn't have two moms. The teacher reading the story then asked the kids in her class how they thought that made the little girl in the story feel. That is when the little boy said that if the teacher were more opened minded she maybe could understood that it was possible for this little girl to have two moms. When asked what he meant by "open-minded" he came up with vegetable metaphor. It had nothing to do with gay sex at all.
 
 There was one teacher who I thought verged on being a tich political - but overall it was an excellent video - and even I learned some things. 
 
 And - there is no hiding this. Kids know about homosexuality - they just all too often have misinformation. But the main thrust of the video is that regardless of what kids or their parents think about homosexuality, kids are aware, it is impacting schools and its OK to talk about.

 Do you have any idea what the book is about? 
 
 "Book Review 
 
 Queering Elementary Education: Advancing the Dialogue about Sexualities in Schooling 
 Edited by William J. Letts IV and James T. Sears (1999) ISBN # 0-8476-9369-4 
 Reviewed by Sarah Page
 Queering Elementary Education is unique because as it's title suggests it does not apologize for the stance that it takes, nor does it wallow in the problems of being homosexual in a heterosexist society. It is a book all educators should read whether they are elementary school teachers, administrators, or college professors. It challenges assumptions about how we view education and how we view caring for children. Edited by William J. Letts IV and James T. Sears, it offers many perspectives on the various aspects of elementary education and the myriad ways it is heterosexist. 
 In the first chapter James T. Sears proposes several ideas that appear throughout the book: speaking the unspoken by teaching about XXXXX issues in elementary school, homosexuality as part of the human condition, and asserting that heterosexism and homophobia are acquired or learned beliefs. Bickmore asks, "why discuss sexuality in elementary school?" and answers "given the amount of (mis)information about gender relations and sexuality that flows freely these days in public spaces, media and peer groups, elementary educators could not prevent children from acquiring sexual information even if they wanted to do so"(p. 15). These concepts as well as others are discussed in various ways throughout the book. 
 The book is divided into five sections: foundational issues, children's sexual and social development, curriculum, family, and educators and their allies. The tone of the book is forthright and determined. It does not focus on the many problems faced by XXXXXX but rather offers overall insight that can be garnered from a new view of education from the XXXXX perspective. While it does not ignore the overwhelming statistics, it is looking for the means to effect change. It addresses the issue of how young we inculcate our children with prejudice and misinformation. Many of the contributors make the link between gender and sexual stereotypes. The connections to racial and ethnic difference are also identified.

 "Book Review 
 
 Queering Elementary Education: Advancing the Dialogue about Sexualities in Schooling 
 Edited by William J. Letts IV and James T. Sears (1999) ISBN # 0-8476-9369-4 
 Reviewed by Sarah Page
 Queering Elementary Education is unique because as it's title suggests it does not apologize for the stance that it takes, nor does it wallow in the problems of being homosexual in a heterosexist society. It is a book all educators should read whether they are elementary school teachers, administrators, or college professors. It challenges assumptions about how we view education and how we view caring for children. Edited by William J. Letts IV and James T. Sears, it offers many perspectives on the various aspects of elementary education and the myriad ways it is heterosexist. 
 In the first chapter James T. Sears proposes several ideas that appear throughout the book: speaking the unspoken by teaching about XXXXX issues in elementary school, homosexuality as part of the human condition, and asserting that heterosexism and homophobia are acquired or learned beliefs. Bickmore asks, "why discuss sexuality in elementary school?" and answers "given the amount of (mis)information about gender relations and sexuality that flows freely these days in public spaces, media and peer groups, elementary educators could not prevent children from acquiring sexual information even if they wanted to do so"(p. 15). These concepts as well as others are discussed in various ways throughout the book. 
 The book is divided into five sections: foundational issues, children's sexual and social development, curriculum, family, and educators and their allies. The tone of the book is forthright and determined. It does not focus on the many problems faced by XXXXXX but rather offers overall insight that can be garnered from a new view of education from the XXXXX perspective. While it does not ignore the overwhelming statistics, it is looking for the means to effect change. It addresses the issue of how young we inculcate our children with prejudice and misinformation. Many of the contributors make the link between gender and sexual stereotypes. The connections to racial and ethnic difference are also identified. 
 By far what makes this book so important is the overall challenge to the ways in which we enact heterosexism, genderism and homophobia within our teaching methods, views, choice of subject matter, choice of reading matter and portrayal of family. Reading it will challenge even those among us who have read it all before. "

 "The Gay Lesbian and Straight Education Network, which boasts membership of more than 1,200 teachers, also has a budget of $3.5 million," Knight said, "and they work all over the country to introduce homosexuality into the school system."  Lesbian suit against Christian school tossed
 'No triable issues': Academy's right to expel 2 girls in 'relationship' confirmed
 
 © 2008 WorldNetDaily.com, Jan. 25, 2008
 
 A California judge has ruled that Christian schools can set standards for behavior for their students, and impose penalties if they are not met.
 
 The decision comes from Riverside County Superior Court Judge Gloria Trask, who found 'no triable issues' on claims that a Christian school discriminated against two girls because of their perceived sexual orientation, according to a report in the North County Times.
 
 Trask recently dismissed the claims made against California Lutheran High School in Wildomar by the two girls and their parents.
 
 The case developed in 2005 when the girls, members of the junior class, were expelled after school officials noticed behavior by the two that may have indicated a lesbian relationship.
 
 The lawsuit filed by the girls and the parents then alleged the California Lutheran High School Association -- which oversees operation of the Wildomar school -- engaged in discrimination, invasion of privacy and unfair business practices in its handling and ultimate dismissal of two juniors.
 
 The students were summoned into the office of Principal Gregory Bork, the lawsuit claimed, where Bork "individually and separately interrogated the (students) in a closed room, without the parents" knowledge or consent ... and asked (them) inappropriate and personal questions such as whether they loved one another and were lesbians.'
 
 "In such a manner, Bork coerced one of the (students) to admit that she 'loves' the other," a court document stated.
 
 The next day, the parents received a phone call from Bork informing them the board had decided to expel the students. One day later, the parents confronted the principal in person and by phone and were told the two girls could not remain at school "with those feelings."
 
 Bork also wrote a letter to the parents stating "while there is no open physical contact between the two girls, there is still a bond of intimacy ... characteristic of a lesbian [relationship]. ... Such a relationship is unchristian. To allow the girls to attend [Cal Lutheran] ... would send a message to students and parents that we either condone this situation and/or will not do anything about it. That message would not reflect our beliefs and principles."
 
 The students, identified in the lawsuit as Jane Doe and Mary Roe, were expelled in September 2005 for "engaging in homosexual conduct in violation of the Christian Code of Conduct, including but not limited to, posing for pictures in suggestive sexual positions."
 
 Lawyers for the students argued the school is not a religious institution but a fee-taking organization.
 
 But they were opposed by other lawyers, from the Christian Legal Society and the Alliance Defense Fund, who argued on behalf of the school, because the decision could affect members of the Association of Faith-Based Organizations.
 
 "Christian schools have the right to make admissions and disciplinary decisions consistent with their Christian beliefs," said Timothy J. Tracey, a litigation counsel for the CLS. "To subject Christian schools to liability under the California anti-discrimination laws for expelling students who engage in homosexual conduct flatly violates this right."
 
 "The 14th Amendment protects the right of parents to send their children to a private religious school that shares their religious beliefs," the arguments said. "The United States Supreme Court has long recognized the existence of parents' right to direct their children's education."
 
 "These parents have chosen to send their children to private Christian schools because of the unique Christian mission and values espoused by the schools. Compelling the schools to condone extramarital sexual conduct contrary to their values and beliefs eliminates a primary reason why parents choose to send their children to these Christian schools in the first place - having their children educated and mentored from a distinctly Christian perspective," the court filings said.
 
 "The state may govern the 'basic requirements' of private schools, through licensing and reporting requirements, but 'it cannot unreasonably interfere with the teaching and educational philosophies of such schools,'" the argument said.
 
 The First Amendment's Religion Clause also prevents state anti-discrimination laws based on moral behavior from applying, the attorneys argued.
 
 Attorney Kirk Hanson, representing the students, said he would appeal the dismissal of the case. He said he'll continue to argue the school is a business and must abide by state discrimination requirements.
 
 "That's (appeals court) where this case would have ended up regardless," Hanson told the newspaper. "Win or lose at the trial level, the case is going to be in front of a court of appeal."
 
 But John McKay, a lawyer for the school, said, "The First Amendment gives Christian schools the right to educate children on the [basis] of Christian beliefs. We're right on the First Amendment [regarding] free association."
 
 On a forums page at the newspaper's Internet site, 'Edward,' supported the decision.
 
 'It's not right to enroll in a school that has certain defined beliefs and rules, and then decide you don't want to comply,' he wrote. 'Simply enroll in a different school that closer matches your idealogy [sic]. Don't sue to try to make the existing school what you want it to be.'
 
 'This was obviously an attack by the 'diversity' crowd on another religious institution," added 'Watch out.' "They are dead set on destroying any mention of or exercise of religious freedom."
 
 And Peter added, 'Think, people, think .... If you as a parent sign on a dotted line accepting the rules of the private school, then disciplinary action against your son or daughter should be expected when they break the rules. Face the consequences and move on."

Playing catchup, I hit this post:
 
what they are attempting to accomplish long term is for Society at large to accept homosexuality as right, normal and as traditional a form of sexual unity and bonding as heterosexuality is. 

 At this point I was scratching my head trying to understand how this differs from what flygirl said about gays wanting to end discrimination. Then I read this part and my mystification only deepened:
 
Because rather than teach that simply respecting peoples differences is right, it teaches that BEING different is right and normal. It justifies homosexuality rather than teaching understanding and sensitivity to the differences between them and us.

 I couldn't understand what you meant at first. How do you teach respect, understanding and sensitivity toward others who are different without portraying them as existing on an equal footing?
 
 Then I got it - a real face/candlestick moment. To you, respecting differences isn't about acknowledging or accepting that other people can be different in their beliefs or sexual preference yet fundamentally equal so long as they do their best not to harm others. To you, respecting peoples differences is about allowing them to be wrong, sinful and deviant. In one sense it's not about other people at all - it's certainly not something you do for the benefit of those whose differences you 'respect': it's something you do in order to feel good about what a wonderfully tolerant and enlightened person you are.
 
 So as far as you're concerned, sure, individuals shouldn't be overtly discriminated against based on their sexuality. But not because discrimination might be unpleasant for them. No: it's because being tolerant and understanding and sensitive is what nice people like you do. What you really can't stand is the idea of future generations respecting others who are different for the wrong reason; doing it out of genuine empathy and a sense of fellowship rather than as an exercise in spiritual masturbation.
